as you can imagine uh there are fields

restart um and we wanted to change that
as well um at that time we also

hot plug for CPU and memory hot plug for
um uh network interfaces and a hot plug
for um discs and volumes however all of
these uh um mechanisms they had uh
different apis to them uh some of them
were declarative some were were
imperative using a sub resource and we
wanted to unify all of this and bring
all of these changes together into the
VM object and um what we've done we

that um effectively turns our VM objects
into live updatable and uh from there uh
Fields uh that can be immediately
propagated such as uh labels and
annotation and others uh can do so and
uh changes to CPU memory for example
would trigger a hot plug and uh other
changes that affect affect the uh guest
ABI these would still require restart
and the user would be notified uh
accordingly building on this uh
functionality we also uh developed a
volume migration mechanism uh this year
and I invite you to uh follow the QR

the on the um on this feature that that
includes a demo and um um a discussion
about um potential use cases um what I
will say here is that uh as I mentioned
before changes to a VM object especially
in the area of of volumes um for example
if somebody wants to change uh the
persistent volume claims on a VM uh this
would trigger a migration although there
are different strategies how to react to
such change um it could be a hot plug or
a replacement of these uh we'll focus on
uh migration here and um a migration is
needed uh because if you remember the uh
uh pod objects kubernetes at the moment
they these are m durable and we cannot
simply change the volumes that are
attached to um um to pods therefore we
need to create a Target pod uh with the
new volumes attached to it with a
similar spec and live migration is
actually doing exactly that for us um so
the flow Works in a way that a change on
the VM object would be recognized uh as
such and then the workload updator
controller would trigger a migration to
create a Target pod with the new volumes
attached and then the content of the
virtual machine would be transferred
from The Source pod um to uh the newly
created one and um those uh who will be
mainly interested in this feature are
users who are willing to migrate um to
move their uh their VMS from one um
storage class to
another and uh there are many reasons
for doing so one of which is uh as for
example the underlying storage needs to
go uh through a maintenance and the
administrator wants to move all of these
workloads to another storage uh without
without any interruptions another use
case for example is that uh uh some
users want to move from block storage to
um file system volumes and uh this uh
process allows this as

important change in in our uh ver
Handler component ver Handler is the uh
node component and and until recently it
was very powerful it was able to see all
the virtual machine instance objects in
the cluster what it was able to process
them and uh it could also see the node
objects and actually change them and um
even before that Chang we already
restricted the the verd Handler uh from
touching any virtual machine objects uh
that are not uh that are not running on
that specific node where uh the ver
Handler itself was running and uh with
the new with this new change uh we

that actually prevents ver Handler from
um from modifying uh um node
specs uh and we also restricted and
prevented from U modif from doing
anything uh to labels and annotations
that were not
um owned by Cube ver meaning uh were put
there by other components for
example um during this year we also uh
developed a um another operator um that
solves a fundamental problem in cubert
and this is an application OFW uh qu um
what it does it presents an alternative
way for managing qu in
kubernetes and
um the fundamental problem that it
solves in cubert is that um um it uh
allows us to avoid um sorry uh I'll say
it differently the um our cubt system
upgrades uh they rely on life migration
and this live migration can be blocked
easily by uh Not Enough by not having
enough qu in the system and um normally
resource qu is being installed in the
Nam space and it consumes resources uh
and limits resources such as CPU and
memory and um on the other hand um as I
said uh we perform system upgrades
through live migration and as part of
live migration we create a Target Port
as as I mentioned before that consumed
the same amount of resources as the
source put and then eventually uh what
happens is that we uh there's a point in
time that we consume double the amount
of resources that are needed for running
a virtual machine and if there's not
enough quot in the system that Target
pod cannot be admitted and eventually uh
the whole system upgrade and other
important operations
uh can fail so this um new operator uh
resolves this issue uh another problem
that it solves for us is related to the
fact that uh other viralization um
platforms they build their users only
for um the virtual resources that they
consume and all the infrastructure
overhead um that is um uh effectively
being uh introduced by the
virtualization stack itself uh it's
being ignored and has nothing to do with
the user um and um in cubert we cannot
simply ignore this overhead and we must
uh list it and it's being counted uh
towards the user quot so this operator
solves this problem for us and it relies
mainly on a feature uh incat that was
recently introduced it's called P
scheduling uh Readiness that effectively
adds a new field uh to a pod spec uh
it's called the scheduling gate and when
this gate is set um the Pod will be
prevented from scheduling and uh it will
be kind of suspended and until the
moment the gate is lifted and uh once
it's lifted uh the Pod will continue
scheduling um to the nodes and we can
rely on this mainly because um both of
our VM creation flow and the migration
flow eventually they create pods and
when these pods are committed to the
system uh the AQ web hook would add this
uh uh scheduling gate to them
effectively suspending them and at that
time uh the AQ controller uh would be
able to recalculate the quot in the
system and um would check if the uh
suspended pods can fit into the
remaining remaining quarter if they do
the gate will be lifted and these will
be uh scheduled to the
nodes same way uh for uh live migration
when we create this target pod um this
target pod would be recognized by the
application work qu controller that it's
actually being part of already um um
running uh virtual machine and um since
we don't want to use uh to build the
users twice uh that Target pod will be
uh scheduled to the node immediately
effectively um unblocking uh live
migrations some benefits that we uh we
get by uh using this uh uh operator
first of all that we remove a bottleneck
uh from the API server where uh
previously resource qu was uh was
calculated and uh because we remove this
bottleneck um the API server can be um
can spend more time processing requests
uh than calculating quot another benefit
is that the API that is coming with the
application of our qu uh allow us to see
um a cluster wide uh consumption qu uh
something that we couldn't get with the
traditional uh resource quot in
kubernetes um where we could see um
resources consumed uh only per specific
name space another benefit um that we
get uh with this operator is that it's
not necessarily have to work with cubber
at all it can work with other objects
